oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Man of the Times Newspaper Article
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This newspaper clipping was an advertisement for Dr. Pierce and his various "medicines." It discusses Dr. Pierce and his "attention to women's diseases" and why his free advice should be sought out. Additionally, a prosecutorial statement follows: "We guarantee that Dr. Pierce's Favorite Prescription does not contain alcohol, opium, or any harmful drug...false statements concerning ingredients will be prosecuted." This statement is a direct result of two lawsuits placed upon Collier's and Ladies Home Journal (both very influential at this time in history) by Pierce. The item is dated between 1906 and 1914 because the Pure Food and Drug Act was created in 1906, and Pierce died in 1914.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Pierce's Alternative Extract or Golden Medical Discovery Bottle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aqua bottle 22 cm x 7.5 cm x 4 cm with paper label on front. Bottle embossed on sides ("R.V. Pierce, M.D." and "Buffalo, N.Y.") and back ("Dr. Pierce's Golden Medical Discovery"). Dr. Pierce's Golden Medical Discovery (or GMD) was one of Pierce's earliest products. This product was called a "vegetable alternative" tonic and was also one of the longest-lasting lines of Pierce's Proprietaries (the company that was formed sometime after the death of the senior Dr. Pierce and continued selling these items well into the 1970s). This product was to be used to help cleanse the body and blood and to "tone the system." A later booklet about the product stated the ingredients of GMD were bloodroot (sanguinaria canadensis), Oregon grape root (berberis aquifolium), stone root (collinsonia canadensis), Queen's root (stillingia sylvatica), sacred bark (rhamnus purshiana), and cherrybark (prunus virginiana).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Pierce's Favorite Prescription Bottle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aqua glass bottle 21 cm x 7.5 cm x 4 cm. Bottle embossed on sides ("R.V. Pierce, M.D." and "Buffalo, N.Y.") and back ("Dr. Pierce's Favorite Prescription"). Front has indications of paper label once affixed. This is another of Pierce's earliest items. In his Common Sense Medical Advisor, Pierce states it "is a tonic nervine of unsurpassed efficacy...quiets nervous irritation, it strengthens the enfeebled nervous system..." This item was also touted as "The Woman's Medicine." One of the more blatant ads for this item states, "Are You Attractive? So Often Women Lose Charm."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Pierce's Invalids Hotel and Surgical Institute booklet
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Pierce's Invalids Hotel and Surgical Institute: 60 Years Experience in This Great Hospital. Buffalo, NY: World's Dispensary Medical Association, 1938(?). Black ink. This booklet highlights the Invalids Hotel established by Pierce in the late 1870s, located at 665 Main Street, Buffalo, NY. More importantly, this booklet shows the advanced equipment and treatment options that were available at the Invalids Hotel in the late 1930s, which included radiation therapy, sun and light therapy, and electrical-current therapy. There is also extensive discussion of urinary-tract diseases and the ability to crush bladder stones without surgery. The "Hotel" continued operating until 1941.
